trans-unit.source: Provides an abstract base class that supports automatic background pagination and tracking content positions across repaginations in addition to the methods and properties of its own base class.

By default, a DynamicDocumentPaginator will automatically pre-paginate content in the background (this process begins when <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.IsBackgroundPaginationEnabled%2A> is `true`, which is the default setting).

When <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.IsBackgroundPaginationEnabled%2A> is `true`, the layout will also be repaginated due to changes in content or changes in <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DocumentPaginator.PageSize%2A>.

The <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.PaginationProgress> event occurs upon completion of pagination (or repagination) of one or more pages, such as in the following situations: - <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.PaginationProgress> events occur as content is paginated in the background.
Depending on the implementation, the event may occur upon paginating one or multiple pages (<xref:System.Windows.Documents.PaginationProgressEventArgs> specifies which pages have been paginated).

- Calls to <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DocumentPaginator.GetPage%2A> or <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DocumentPaginator.GetPageAsync%2A> may cause an <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.PaginationProgress> event to occur if the page specified has not been paginated.

For example, if background pagination is enabled (<xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.IsBackgroundPaginationEnabled%2A> = `true`) but pagination has only been completed up to the third page, a call of <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DocumentPaginator.GetPage%2A> with an argument of 6 will cause pages four, five, six, and seven to be paginated.

Upon completion, a <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.PaginationProgress> event will be raised with <xref:System.Windows.Documents.PaginationProgressEventArgs> settings of <xref:System.Windows.Documents.PaginationProgressEventArgs.Start%2A> = 4 and <xref:System.Windows.Documents.PaginationProgressEventArgs.Count%2A> = 4.

- With background pagination enabled (<xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.IsBackgroundPaginationEnabled%2A> = `true`), a change in <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DocumentPaginator.PageSize%2A> on flow-format content, such as a <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument>, may cause repagination and associated <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.PaginationProgress> events.

Note that <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DocumentPaginator.PageSize%2A> has no effect in repagination on fixed-format content, such as <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FixedDocument>, where the visual page size does not affect the layout.
A <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.PaginationCompleted> event also occurs when background pagination is disabled.

For example, if there is only one page of content and <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.IsBackgroundPaginationEnabled%2A> = `false`), calling <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DocumentPaginator.GetPage%2A> with an argument of 0 will result in two events: 1.

A <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.PaginationProgress> event with <xref:System.Windows.Documents.PaginationProgressEventArgs> settings of <xref:System.Windows.Documents.PaginationProgressEventArgs.Start%2A> = 0 and <xref:System.Windows.Documents.PaginationProgressEventArgs.Count%2A> = 1.
A <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.PaginationCompleted> event.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator"></xref> class.
When overridden in a derived class, returns a <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.ContentPosition"></xref> for the specified <xref:System.Object>.
The object to return the <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.ContentPosition"></xref> of.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.ContentPosition"></xref> of the given object.
When overridden in a derived class, returns the zero-based page number of the specified <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.ContentPosition"></xref>.
If pages prior to the `contentPosition` have not been formatted, they will be paginated synchronously prior to returning the requested page number.
<xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.GetPageNumberAsync%2A> provides similar functionality as GetPageNumber, but with asynchronous operation.
The content position whose page number is needed.
An representing zero-based page number where the specified contentPosition appears.

Asynchronously, returns (through the This method raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.GetPageNumberCompleted"></xref> event) the zero-based page number of the specified <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.ContentPosition"></xref>.
The only way to cancel the asynchronous operation of this method is to cancel all asynchronous operations.
Contrast this with the other overload of this method: <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.GetPageNumberAsync%28System.Windows.Documents.ContentPosition%2CSystem.Object%29>.
This method raises the <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.GetPageNumberCompleted> event.
The page number is passed to the event as one of the event arguments.
See <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.GetPageNumberAsync%28System.Windows.Documents.ContentPosition%2CSystem.Object%29> for how to use this method to get the page number.
The content position whose page number is needed.

Asynchronously, returns (through the This method raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.GetPageNumberCompleted"></xref> event) the zero-based page number of the specified <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.ContentPosition"></xref>.
This overload of the method makes it possible to cancel this asynchronous operation without cancelling all asynchronous operations.
This method raises the <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.GetPageNumberCompleted> event.
The following steps illustrate how to retrieve the page number of a given `contentPosition` asynchronously.

Create a <xref:System.Windows.Documents.GetPageNumberCompletedEventHandler> delegate and add it to be notified of <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.GetPageNumberCompleted> events.
Call GetPageNumberAsync specifying the `contentPosition` desired and a unique `userState` object that will be used to identify the asynchronous task.

When the event occurs and the delegate is called, compare the event's <xref:System.Windows.Documents.GetPageNumberCompletedEventArgs>.<xref:System.ComponentModel.AsyncCompletedEventArgs.UserState%2A> property with the original GetPageNumberAsync `userState` parameter.

When the <xref:System.Windows.Documents.GetPageNumberCompletedEventArgs>.<xref:System.ComponentModel.AsyncCompletedEventArgs.UserState%2A> property matches the original GetPageNumberAsync `userState`, the operation is complete and the page number is ready.

(The <xref:System.Windows.Documents.GetPageNumberCompletedEventArgs>.<xref:System.Windows.Documents.GetPageNumberCompletedEventArgs.ContentPosition%2A> property will also match the original GetPageNumberAsync `contentPosition` parameter.) 5.

The <xref:System.Windows.Documents.GetPageNumberCompletedEventArgs>.<xref:System.Windows.Documents.GetPageNumberCompletedEventArgs.PageNumber%2A> property contains the zero-based page number of the specified `contentPosition`.

<xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.GetPageNumber%2A> provides similar functionality as <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.GetPageNumberAsync%2A>, but for synchronous operation.
The content position element to return the page number of.
A unique identifier for the asynchronous task.
Occurs when <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.GetPageNumberAsync*> has completed.
To be added.
When overridden in a derived class, gets the position of the specified page in the document's content.
The page whose position is needed.
A representing the position of page.
Gets or sets a value indicating whether pagination is performed automatically in the background in response to certain events, such as a change in page size.

When `true`, pagination is performed in the background, raising <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.PaginationProgress> and <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.PaginationCompleted> events as appropriate.

Pagination of <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FixedDocument> content, as distinct from a <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument> is not affected by changes to the visual <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DocumentPaginator.PageSize%2A>.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if background pagination is enabled; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
The default is <xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref>.
Raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.GetPageNumberCompleted"></xref> event.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.GetPageNumberCompletedEventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
Raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.PaginationCompleted"></xref> event.
An <xref:System.EventArgs> that contains the event data.
Raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.PaginationProgress"></xref> event.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.PaginationProgressEventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
Occurs when all document content has been paginated.
When PaginationCompleted occurs, <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DocumentPaginator.IsPageCountValid%2A> is `true` until a new pagination is initiated.
To be added.
Occurs when one or more content pages have been paginated.

<xref:System.Windows.Documents.PaginationProgressEventArgs> properties <xref:System.Windows.Documents.PaginationProgressEventArgs.Start%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Documents.PaginationProgressEventArgs.Count%2A> identify the range of pages paginated.
To be added.
